Hi,

Well, my opinion is maybe not an answer to your
problem, but it could help in the future.

Junit comes  from xUnit a framework developped in
collaboration with Kent Beck who is the XP (Extreme
Programming) guru.
And in XP we have a typical way to handle tests...
really simple : Test First!

So when you are developping code you are doing
something like :

1) read the requirement
2) have an idea on how the unit should behave
3) write the tests (in a unit test) you need, to
prouve that the requirement is working/done
4) compile... of course this will not compile because
you' ve just implemented the tests
5) fix the the compilation problems. Actually write
the simplest thing that make your code compile.
6) compile. Now it should compile! :)
7) run the tests, they should fail!
8) fix the unit to make your tests run
9) run you tests, they should run now!
10) you are done!

During the day, i'm working for a contract that needs
to add unit testing (and mockobjects) to an existing
library and i meet the same problems that you have....
I have to rewrite some things to  make the ctor
simpler, but without unit testing how do i know that i
broke anything ?.... Adding unit testing to something
(class or library) is a very risky process that's why
it should not be done this way.

I used to write my class before my unit test, till   i
decided  to try to write my test first (as everybody
says in the XP community)... it completly change my
life (aka my way to code! :))

Hope it helps

Jerome.
